name: Annotation.Svg

values.name: boundingBox
values.comment:
Svg view of a bounding box with default style.
Default style is defined in `Annotation.Style`.

values.name: boundingBoxStyled
values.comment: Svg view of a bounding box with given style.

values.name: boundingBoxWithDetails
values.comment:
Svg detailed view of a bounding box.

Specify in the attributes the style of the bounding box.
Alternatively put a class attribute and set those in a style sheet (CSS).

The attributes arguments are appended to the already provided ones
which are the geometric attributes (position and size) of the bounding box.

Most often, you will also want to add `pointerEvents "none"`
to prevent unwanted pointer events from happening.
It is added by default in the `boundingBox` and `boundingBoxStyled`
functions but not in `boundingBoxWithDetails`.

values.name: contour
values.comment:
Svg view of a contour with default style.
Default style is defined in `Annotation.Style`.

values.name: contourStyled
values.comment: Svg view of a contour with given style.

values.name: contourWithDetails
values.comment:
Svg detailed view of a contour.

Specify in the attributes the style of the contour.
Alternatively put a class attribute and set those in a style sheet (CSS).

The attributes arguments are appended to the already provided ones
which are the geometric attributes (contour points positions).

Most often, you will also want to add `pointerEvents "none"`
to prevent unwanted pointer events from happening.
It is added by default in the `contour` and `contourStyled`
functions but not in `contourWithDetails`.

values.name: outline
values.comment:
Svg view of an outline with default style.
Default style is defined in `Annotation.Style`.

values.name: outlineStyled
values.comment: Svg view of an outline with given style.

values.name: outlineWithDetails
values.comment:
Svg detailed view of an outline.

Specify in the attributes the style of the outline.
Alternatively put a class attribute and set those in a style sheet (CSS).

The attributes arguments are appended to the already provided ones
which are the geometric attributes (outline points positions).

Most often, you will also want to add `pointerEvents "none"`
to prevent unwanted pointer events from happening.
It is added by default in the `outline` and `outlineStyled`
functions but not in `outlineWithDetails`.

values.name: point
values.comment:
Svg view of a point with default style.
Default style is defined in `Annotation.Style`.

values.name: pointStyled
values.comment: Svg view of a point with given style.

values.name: pointWithDetails
values.comment:
Svg detailed view of a point.

Specify in the attributes the radius and styling of the disk
used to represent the point. Alternatively, put a class attribute
and set those in a style sheet (CSS).

The attributes arguments are appended to the already provided ones
which are the circle center point coordinates (`cx`, `cy`).

Most often, you will also want to add `pointerEvents "none"`
to prevent unwanted pointer events from happening.
It is added by default in the `point` and `pointStyled` functions
but not in `pointWithDetails`.

values.name: stroke
values.comment:
Svg view of a stroke with default style.
Default style is defined in `Annotation.Style`.

values.name: strokeStyled
values.comment: Svg view of a stroke with given style.

values.name: strokeWithDetails
values.comment:
Svg detailed view of a stroke.

Specify in the attributes the style of the stroke.
Alternatively put a class attribute and set those in a style sheet (CSS).

The attributes arguments are appended to the already provided ones
which are the geometric attributes (line points positions).

Most often, you will also want to add `pointerEvents "none"`
to prevent unwanted pointer events from happening.
It is added by default in the `stroke` and `strokeStyled`
functions but not in `strokeWithDetails`.

name: Annotation.Geometry.Stroke
comment:
Create and manipulate free line strokes.

The stroke type is an alias for the [OpenSolid Geometry Polyline2d][polyline2d]
type so if a functionality is not provided by this module,
you can easily extend it with functions from the OpenSolid/Geometry package.

[polyline2d]: http://package.elm-lang.org/packages/opensolid/geometry/2.0.1/OpenSolid-Polyline2d#Polyline2d

@docs empty, addPoint, fromPoints, close

values.name: addPoint
values.comment: Add a point to an unfinished stroke.

values.name: close
values.comment:
Close a stroke (polyline) into a polygon.

The output can be interpreted as a either a `Contour` or an `Outline`
since both are OpenSolid polygons type aliases.

values.name: empty
values.comment: Create an empty stroke.

values.name: fromPoints
values.comment: Create a stroke from a list of points

name: Annotation.Style

types.name: Fill
types.comment:
Styling of a content (fill).

A fill is either not visible, or of a given color.
Opacity is set using the alpha channel of the color.

types.name: Line
types.comment:
Styling of a line.

A line is either not visible,
or displayed with a stroke of given width and color.

types.name: Point
types.comment:
Styling of a point.

A point is either not visible,
or displayed as a colored disk of a given radius.

values.name: fillAttribute
values.comment: Transform a Fill style into the corresponding svg attribute.

values.name: fillDefault
values.comment:
Default style of a content (fill)

A red with opacity at 20%.

values.name: pointDefault
values.comment:
Default style of a point.

An orange disk of radius 3 px.

values.name: strokeAttributes
values.comment: Transform a Line style into the corresponding svg attributes.

values.name: strokeDefault
values.comment:
Default style of a line.

A red stroke of width 2 px.

values.name: fromCoordinates
values.comment: Create a Point with the given coordinates.

name: Annotation.Geometry.Contour
comment:
Create and manipulate polygonal contours.

The `Contour` type is an alias for the [OpenSolid Geometry Polygon2d][polygon2d]
type so if a functionality is not provided by this module,
you can easily extend it with functions from the OpenSolid/Geometry package.

[polygon2d]: http://package.elm-lang.org/packages/opensolid/geometry/2.0.1/OpenSolid-Polygon2d#Polygon2d

@docs empty, fromPoints

values.name: empty
values.comment: Create an empty contour.

values.name: fromPoints
values.comment: Create a contour from a list of points.

name: Annotation.Geometry.Outline
comment:
Create and manipulate free line closed outlines.

The `Outline` type is an alias for the [OpenSolid Geometry Polygon2d][polygon2d]
type so if a functionality is not provided by this module,
you can easily extend it with functions from the OpenSolid/Geometry package.

[polygon2d]: http://package.elm-lang.org/packages/opensolid/geometry/2.0.1/OpenSolid-Polygon2d#Polygon2d

@docs empty, fromPoints

values.name: empty
values.comment: Create an empty outline.

values.name: fromPoints
values.comment: Create a closed outline from a list of points.

name: Annotation.Viewer

aliases.name: Viewer
aliases.type: { frame : OpenSolid.Frame2d.Frame2d , size : ( Float, Float ) , zoom : Float }

values.name: centerAt
values.comment: Recenter the viewing area at a given point.

values.name: default
values.comment: Default viewer.

values.name: fitImage
values.comment: Fit the view so that the image takes a certain percentage of its max viewable size.

values.name: getCenter
values.comment: Compute the center point of the viewer.

values.name: grabMove
values.comment: Translate the viewer frame opposite to the vector (used for "grab and move").

values.name: placeIn
values.comment:
Place an svg element in a viewer (apply the appropriate frame transformation).

This is for a user who wants to keep full control of the viewing process.
The result can then be used as a regular svg element.

It does not compute new coordinates of each svg element,
but simply embeds them in a group with the appropriate transformation.
So try using it only once, on a group containing all elements to insert.

For simple viewing, prefer using the `viewIn` function.

values.name: positionIn
values.comment: Transform coordinates of a point in the frame to their actual image coordinates.

values.name: setSize
values.comment: Reset size of the viewer.

values.name: setZoom
values.comment: Set the zoom value.

values.name: setZoomCentered
values.comment: Set zoom value while keeping the current center.

values.name: sizeIn
values.comment: Scale a size in the frame to its actual image size.

values.name: viewIn
values.comment:
View the generated svg annotations (bounding boxes, contours, ...)
in the viewer.

For display of the corresponding image in background,
simply group it with the annotations to generate a new Svg msg:

    Svg.g [] [ Image.viewSvg [] image, svgAnnotations ]

Be aware that the output of `viewIn` is an `svg` tag embedded in a `div` tag.
Embedding is performed to remedy some inconsistencies that may occur when
trying to get the dimensions of an `svg` tag with `clientWidth`.
(see [W3C spec](https://www.w3.org/TR/cssom-view-1/#dom-element-clientwidth):
"If the element has no associated CSS layout box
or if the CSS layout box is inline, return zero.")

For finer-grained control, prefer using `placeIn`.

values.name: viewInWithDetails
values.comment: Same as `viewIn` but html attributes can be added (like class, ...).
values.type: List (Html.Attribute msg) -> Annotation.Viewer.Viewer -> Svg.Svg msg -> Html.Html msg

values.name: zoomIn
values.comment: Zoom in (x2).

values.name: zoomOut
values.comment: Zoom out (x0.5).

name: Annotation.Geometry.BoundingBox
comment:
Create and manipulate bounding boxes.

@docs fromPair, svgAttributes

values.name: fromPair
values.comment:
Create a bounding box from a pair of points
representing opposite corners of the bounding box.

values.name: svgAttributes
values.comment: Get the geometric svg attributes of a bounding box.

values.name: palette
values.comment:
A color palette print and color-blind friendly.

( beige, green, turquoise, blue, dark blue )

values.name: toStr
values.comment: Get a string describing the color like `rgba(255,0,0,1)`.

values.name: turquoise
values.comment: Turquoise.

name: Annotation.Geometry.Types
comment:
Types of the different elements usable for annotations.

In order to initialize an object of one of these types,
look into the corresponding module.
For example, to initialize a `Point`,
you will use the `Point.fromCoordinates` function from the `Point` module.

Rmq: _All those types are aliases of other types
from the [OpenSolid Geometry][OpenSolid] package.
So you can easily extend functionalities based on the Opensolid functions._

[OpenSolid]: http://package.elm-lang.org/packages/opensolid/geometry/2.0.1

@docs Point, BoundingBox, Contour, Outline, Stroke

aliases.name: Outline
aliases.comment:
An outline.

The main difference with a contour is the context of usage.
A contour is more likely to have few identified nodes,
while an outline is more like a continuous line.
